posts.cooked:
Hi folks,

as Greyson Parrelli (from the Signal Team) stated in a GitHub comment,

deleting […] media (via the media viewer, or “all media” screen) will also delete the message itself.

Well, I can confirm this, but that was not what (I guess) someone is expecting when you’re going to delete media, since the media technically (and IMHO logically as well) is just a part of the message and should be handled appropriately (like anywhere else, e. g. when copying messages, creating backups etc.). The way it seems to be implemented right now does delete every piece of text (and that again is most often the most valuable content) contained in the message the media belongs to as well.

I’d even consider this behavior as a bug, because I don’t want to batch delete whole messages (including text) when cleaning up space by deleting pictures for example…

Is there a reason for not at least keeping the text of a message (if it’s not a media-only message) and just insert a placeholder like in this commit (or even better: optionally keep/embed a thumbnail of the deleted media)? IIRC, the PR #6165 from @haffenloher did it that way, but was closed after Greyson implemented the (batch) media deletion.

Greyson said, that the current behavior is worth a discussion. So what’s your opinion on this?

posts.cooked:
PiCob:

Is there a reason for not at least keeping the text of a message (if it’s not a media-only message) and just insert a placeholder like in this commit (or even better: optionally keep/embed a thumbnail of the deleted media)?

I agree, keeping the message text with a placeholder thumbnail (as shown in the Github link) would be a perfect solution to this. I would prefer the placeholder over an embedded thumbnail to prevent confusion for anyone who forgets they deleted media (and may accidentally assume that Signal is compressing the hell out of their photos.)

posts.cooked: Weird… a minute before you wrote this, I coincidentally just did exactly that Must have been a kind of telepathy ^^

I would not expect nor want the text content to be deleted when the media is deleted.
If there’s a clear dialog which explains that text will also be deleted then I can learn to live with it.

posts.name: ⚠️ abandoned account ⚠️
posts.cooked: there is a general dialog with “delete” and “cancel” buttons (also for ONLY image messages)

2-4601:

If there’s a clear dialog which explains that text will also be deleted

Still, you wouldn’t be able to free up space by deleting media without losing all associated texts This renders the deletion function pretty useless for me.

+1. I had the exact same problem while i was deleting media files in order to gain disk space. I didn’t expect at all that the whole message would be deleted.

PiCob:

Still, you wouldn’t be able to free up space by deleting media without losing all associated texts This renders the deletion function pretty useless for me.

As most people wanting to delete media files are struggling with storage size limitation, I’d like to point to an additional proposed solution, an easy fix to for all the ones with external storage: (please use the Like button there if you think that would help you)

Allow installation on external storage location (SD-card) Android Feature Requests
Me - and I guess many other users with limited internal storage - would love to be able to install/move Signal on the phone’s SD-card. (…and subsequently have the heavy media-files there too) To allow the android system to install Signal on the external storage, you can include the android:installLocation attribute in the <manifest> element, with a value of ‘auto’. → see here Other popular apps that allow it are: Telegram, Instagram, Waze, OsmAnd, Trello, Riot.im… “Feature” was already twi…

link_counts.title: Allow installation on external storage location (SD-card)

posts.name: Greyson Parrelli
posts.cooked: Hey folks, thanks for the feedback! We chose the current behavior after looking at how photo deletion works in other messaging apps. We also try to be clear in the delete confirmation popup by saying “This will permanently delete the selected message.” However, I understand that this can still be confusing. I’ll float it by the team and see what everyone thinks. Just keep in mind that there’s lots of work and few hands, so things take time

What do you think if a message shows that the media file is deleted and on second line the text message with media show.

Media file is deleted
Good morning

Like this?

posts.name: Marc Schulz-Narres
posts.cooked:
I and everyone I talked to agree to @PiCob that this is neither the behaviour the default user expects, nor wants.
If i want to delete a message I select a message. When deleting media I want to only delete media without side effects.
I would prefer a low resolution Thumbnail for context over a placeholder.

EDIT: Additionally this: Archive media and replace with thumbnails would probably fix the reason why most people want to delete pictures in bulk.

link_counts.title: Archive media and replace with thumbnails

In combination with:

Allow selecting all media in overview

signalapp:master ← FeuRenard:select-all-media
opened 05:43PM - 18 Jul 18 UTC
FeuRenard
+23 -0

### Contributor checklist - [x] I am following the [Code Style Guidelines](ht…tps://github.com/signalapp/Signal-Android/wiki/Code-Style-Guidelines) - [x] I have tested my contribution on these devices: * AVD Nexus 5X, Android 7.1.1 - [x] My contribution is fully baked and ready to be merged as is - [x] I ensure that all the open issues my contribution fixes are mentioned in the commit message of my first commit using the `Fixes #1234` [syntax](https://help.github.com/articles/closing-issues-via-commit-messages/) ---------- ### Description This change allows selecting all media in the media overview section. You can do so by long-pressing one item and then tap the select-all icon in the action bar. This feature allows deleting all media of a conversation at once, e.g. to free some disk space. With a save button in the media overview one could export those media in advance. ### Screenshot ![bildschirmfoto vom 2018-07-18 19-29-22](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/16167751/42897949-fbd8e6b8-8ac1-11e8-9481-cee609da1f79.png)

it would be a great way to free up space and keep the conversation intact.

Marc

posts.cooked:
@greyson-signal: Have you already had the chance to float this by the team? I think the introduction of multiple attachments per message would be a great opportunity to implement the new behavior (instead of deleting the whole message including text as soon as the last attachment is deleted). As you can see, nobody seems to be in favor of the current behavior - it’s rather quite the opposite…

Merry Xmas!

posts.name: Meteor0id
posts.cooked:
MarcSN311:

I made a pullrequest, that adds a button to replace an image with a low resolution thumbnail: https://github.com/signalapp/Signal-Android/pull/8510

Nevermind this, I changed my mind

Although the resolution might be so low that whatever was depicted can’t be easily recognized, to someone who remembers what image was there it might still be upsetting to see the contours are still there. It might be better to replace the image entirely by some small placeholder image or text, rather than generating a low resolution thumbnail for it.

Undoubtedly people would come in asking “How do i also delete the thumbnail without deleting the text?”

Actually, never mind what I wrote above. Since this isn’t about deleting the image, but since it is a solution to archive the media, replacing it with low resolution thumbnail might be a very good idea, so one can still get a sense which media was where in the conversation without having to unarchive the media to see it.

What is the behavior for gifs?
Thanks, great idea and I hope it gets merged

posts.name: Meteor0id
posts.cooked: Probably only shows the initial frame at low resolution, but I haven’t checked to code.
